Title: EAGER: Contaminant Transport Behavior in and at the Interface of Fine-Grained Sediments; Visualization, Simulation and Analysis

EPA estimates that there are 235,000 to 355,000 contaminated groundwater sites across the United States that require remediation. The annual operation and maintenance costs, per site undergoing remediation, are estimated to range from $610,000 to $770,000. It is well known that contaminants behave differently in fine grained sediments and may lead to long term contamination of groundwater used as a source of drinking water. However, in spite of this high level of concern there is very little known about the behavior of contaminants that reside in these fine grained formations. It is therefore critical that the fundamental physical-chemical mechanisms responsible for contaminant behavior in fine-grained formations be thoroughly understood. The resulting analysis will elucidate the mechanisms that govern the long-term tailing phenomena observed in contaminated groundwater sites. Such contaminant tailing impacts industry financially, not only because of the direct costs, but also because of their requirement to hold money in reserve to assure long-term financial support for site remediation. The general public, government and industry seek to accelerate groundwater contamination cleanup and this research is designed to help satisfy this need. Finally, this proposal seeks directly to increase the number of women in engineering. The vehicle is the Engineering Institute that is one of four STEM components of the Governor's Institutes of Vermont.

The combination of experimental investigation, modeling and analysis proposed in this proposal to address a critical environmental need will yield the following expected outcomes; 1) the transport behavior of dissolved solutes in media characterized by fine and coarse grained materials separated by a sharp interface will be revealed both qualitatively and quantitatively as a function of time using a novel MRI technology, 2) the veracity of current theory to capture the transport behavior in this system will be evaluated through the fusion of experimental results and transport modeling, and, 3) the experimental results in combination with the modeling will be analyzed to uncover the factors impacting the contaminant-tailing phenomenon which is critical to cost-effective groundwater remediation. The transformative outcomes will be achieved by; 1) employing novel MRI technology to reveal the behavior of tracer transport in porous media, 2) employing mathematical modeling to simulate the behavior observed in the MRI experiments, and, 3) combining experimental and mathematical modeling results to analyze the impact of the movement of tracers in fine-grained media separated from a coarse-grained host by a sharp interface.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Groundwater reservoirs are typically composed of  fine and coarse grained sediments often separated by a sharp interface. While the removal of contaminants from coarse grained sediments  can in many cases appear to be achieved using several different remedial techniques, in fact contaminants can reside in fine grained sediments for very long periods of time. As a result, after the coarse grained sediments appear to be remediated, contaminants from fine-grained sediments may continue to leach into the coarse-grained sediments. The result is an extended period when low levels of contaminant derived from the fine-grained sediments enter the coarse-grained sediments, This is known as a tailing effect.

The goal of this project was to study this phenomenon; that is the leaching of contaminants from fine grained sediments into coarse-grained sediments. Specifically the project focused on the behavior of the contaminants at the interface between the fine and coarse-grained sediments. The work consisted of both an experimental and modeling component.

A unique aspect of the experimental element of this work was the use of a medical MRI device to view behavior inside of a column that contained both fine and coarse grained media arranged such that a sharp interface separated them.

The apparatus is shown in the first figure. The column when packed and saturated with water received dye via a connector on the end of the column. The second figure shows the progress of the system after dye had been injected for four days. In the left panel the red is the dye and the blue is the residual dye-free water as observed in the experiment. In the right panel are presented the results of a mathematical model created to simulate the system.

Note the blue tail at the bottom of the picture. This is due to the convergence of flow from the left and from the right at the bottom of the  column. The result is a zone of stagnation that retains the dye-free water.

Secondly note the bright-red ring located along the interface of the fine and coarse grained material. The anomalously high value of the dye at this interface appears here and in all of our experiments. No explanation for this phenomenon currently exists and the origin of this behavior remains an open question.

The experiments and mathematical model demonstrated that the time required to remove contaminants from fine-grained soil can be very long. This is of enormous importance in devising an engineering plan for site cleanup. The observed tailing behavior was also  illustrated using the mathematical model as applied to a carefully documented field site.

Broader Impacts: The cost-effective design of groundwater remediation strategies is critical to the cleanup of the Nation's contaminated groundwater. Such a design requires understanding of the flow of groundwater and the transport of solutes. Moreover, to forecast the behavior of proposed designs requires a mathematical model. Such a model was created in this research.

Revelation of the unusual and unexplaindd physics occurring at the fine-grained coarse-grained interface  was achieved in this research. This will be of great significance in groundwater remediation design.

The material developed during this research is now embedded in the notes employed in teaching groundwater hydrology at the University of Vermont (UVM). In addition this research has been presented at club meetings of students at UVM and a presentation was prepared for and presented at the Governor's Institute at UVM. This institute consists of especially talented high-school students who are selected to participate at UVM during the course of the summer. Finally the results of this work were provided as a published paper and as formal presentations at an international meeting and at sister institutions.
